                                      • Chapter 7 Exercise 1

                                      Riemann-Stieltjes integrals

                                      7.1

                                      Prove that ∫abdα(x)=α(b)−α(a) directly from Definition 7.1.

                                      Proof

                                      This is a special case of integrals for the constant function f=1, thus for a partition P={x0,x1,…,xn} of [a,b], we consider the Riemann-Stieltjes sum

                                      S(P,1,α)=∑k=1nΔαk=α(b)−α(a)

                                      which shows that S(P,1,α) equals α(b)−α(a) regardless of which partition to choose.

                                      7.2

                                      If f∈R on [a,b] and if ∫abfdα=0 for every f which is monotonic on [a,b], prove that α must be constant on [a,b].

                                      Proof

                                      Let f=1 on [a,b], we get α(b)−α(a)=0 from Exercise 7.1. Assume α is not constant on [a,b], then there exist c∈(a,b) such that α(c)≠α(b). Let f be defined as

                                      f(x)={0,x∈[a,c)1,x∈[c,b]

                                      then f is monotonic on [a,b], and

                                      0=∫abfdα=∫acfdα+∫cbfdα=∫cbdα=α(b)−α(c)≠0

                                      which is a contradiction.

                                      7.3

                                      The following definition of a Riemann-Stieltjes integral is often used in the literature:

                                      We say f is integrable with respect to α if there exists a real number A having the property that for every ε>0 there exists a δ>0 such that for every partition P of [a,b] with norm ∥P∥<δ and for every choice of tk in [xk−1,xk], we have |S(P,f,α)−A|<ε.

                                      a) Show that if ∫abfdα exists according to this definition, then it also exists according to Definition 7.1 and the two integrals are equal.

                                      b) Let f(x)=α(x)=0 for a≤x<c, f(x)=α(x)=1 for c<x≤b, f(c)=0,α(c)=1. Show that ∫abfdα exists according to Definition 7.1 but does not exist by this second definition.

                                      Solution

                                      (a) For ∀ε>0, we can get a δ>0 which satisfy the condition in this definition. Choose a partition Pε of [a,b] with norm ∥Pε∥<δ. If P is any partition finer than Pε, we have ∥P∥≤∥Pε∥<δ, thus for every choice of tk in [xk−1,xk], we have |S(P,f,α)−A|<ε. This shows ∫abfdα exists according to Definition 7.1. Both integrals equal to A.

                                      (b) For ∀ε>0, , let Pε={a,c,b}, then choose any t1∈[a,c] and t2∈[c,b], we have

                                      S(Pε,f,α)=f(t1)(α(c)−α(a))+f(t2)(α(b)−α(c))=0(1)+f(t2)0=0

                                      If P is any partition of [a,b] finer than Pε, then P={a=x0,x1,…,xn=b} and there exist some integer m∈[1,n−1] such that xm=c, thus f(tk)=0 when k≤m and Δαk=0 when k>m, which means

                                      S(P,f,α)=∑k=1nf(tk)Δαk=∑k=1mf(tk)Δαk+∑k=m+1nf(tk)Δαk=0

                                      According to Definition 7.1, we get ∫abfdα=0.

                                      However, for any δ>0, choose integer N such that 1/N<δ, then there exist an integer n such that

                                      a+nN<b≤a+n+1N

                                      we can form a partition P of [a,b] to be

                                      P={a,a+1N,…,a+nN,b}

                                      if there happens to have some integer m which makes c=a+mN, we substitute the point a+mN in P with two point a+m−1/2N and a+m+1/2N. Thus we can form a partition P with ∥P∥<δ and c∉P. Let the points adjacent to c be marked with p,q, we have either p=a+k−1N<c<q=a+kN or p=a+k−1/2N<c<q=a+k+1/2N, and

                                      S(P,f,α)=f(t)(α(q)−α(p))=f(t),t∈[p,q]

                                      if we choose t∈[p,c), then S(P,f,α)=0, if choose t∈[c,q], then S(P,f,α)=1.

                                      7.4

                                      If f∈R according to Definition 7.1, prove that ∫abf(x)dx also exists according to the definition of Exercise 7.3.

                                      Proof

                                      Remark: The key point that Definition 7.1 and definition in Exercise 7.3 are equal, as we proved in this exercise, is that we are talking about Riemann integrals instead of Riemann-Stieltjes integral.

                                      Let I=∫abf(x)dx and M=sup{|f(x)|:x∈[a,b]}. Given ε>0, choose Pε such that U(Pε,f)<I+ε/2. Let N be the number of subdivision points in Pε and let δ=ε/(2MN). If ∥P∥<δ, write

                                      U(P,f)=∑kMk(f)Δxk=S1+S2

                                      where S1 is the sum of terms arising from those subintervals of P containing no points of Pε and S2 the sum of the remaining terms. Then

                                      S1≤U(Pε,f)<I+ε/2,S2≤NM∥P∥<NMδ=ε/2

                                      and hence U(P,f)<I+ε. Similarly we can find some δ′ such that ∥P∥<δ′ means L(P,f)>I−ε. Hence |S(P,f)−I|<ε if ∥P∥<min(δ,δ′).

                                      7.5

                                      Let {an} be a sequence of real numbers. For x≥0, define

                                      A(x)=∑n≤xan=∑n=1[x]an,

                                      where [x] is the greatest integer in x and empty sums are interpreted as zero. Let f have a continuous derivative in the interval 1≤x≤a. Use Stieltjes integrals to derive the following formula:

                                      ∑n≤aanf(n)=−∫1aA(x)f′(x)dx+A(a)f(a).

                                      Solution

                                      f is continuous on [1,a] and A(x) is a step function on [1,a], thus f∈R(A) by Theorem 7.11 and

                                      ∫1afdA=∑n=2[x]f(n)[A(n+)−A(n−)]=∑n=2[x]f(n)an

                                      On the other hand, we have

                                      ∫1afdA+∫1aAdf=A(a)f(a)−A(1)f(1)

                                      since f has continuous derivative, we have

                                      ∫1aAdf=∫1aA(x)f′(x)dx=A(a)f(a)−A(1)f(1)−∫1af(x)dA(x)

                                      use A(1)=a1, we have

                                      A(1)f(1)+∫1af(x)dA(x)=∑n=1[x]f(n)an=∑n≤aanf(n)=−∫1aA(x)f′(x)dx+A(a)f(a).

                                      7.6

                                      Use Euler's summation formula, or integration by parts in a Stieltjes integral, to derive the following identities:

                                      a)∑k=1n1ks=1ns−1+s∫1n[x]xs+1dxif s≠1.b)∑k=1n1k=log⁡n−∫1nx−[x]x2dx+1

                                      Solution

                                      (a) Use the integer part of Euler’s summation formula, we have

                                      ∑k=1n1ks=∫1n1xsdx+∫1n(1xs)′(x−[x]−12)dx+12(1+1ns)

                                      if s≠1, then

                                      ∫1n(1xs)′(x−[x]−12)dx=−s∫1n1xs+1(x−[x]−12)dx=−s∫1n1xsdx+s∫1n[x]xs+1dx−12(1ns−1)

                                      combined with the first equation, we have

                                      ∑k=1n1ks=(1−s)∫1n1xsdx+s∫1n[x]xs+1dx−12(1ns−1)+12(1ns+1)=1ns−1−1+1+s∫1n[x]xs+1dx=1ns−1+s∫1n[x]xs+1dx

                                      (b) We have

                                      ∑k=1n1k=∫1n1xdx−∫1n1x2(x−[x]−12)dx+12(1+1n)

                                      Since

                                      12∫1n1x2+12(1+1n)=−12(1n−1)+12(1+1n)=1

                                      we have

                                      ∑k=1n1k=∫1n1xdx−∫1n1x2(x−[x])dx+1=log⁡n−∫1nx−[x]x2dx+1

                                      7.7

                                      Assume f′ is continuous on [1,2n] and use Euler's summation formula or integration by parts to prove that

                                      ∑k=12n(−1)kf(k)=∫12nf′(x)([x]−2[x/2])dx.

                                      Proof

                                      Use formula in Exercise 7.5 we let an=(−1)n, then for 1≤x≤2n, we have A(x)=∑n=1[x]an, thus A(x)=0 if x∈[2k,2k+1) and A(x)=−1 if x∈[2k+1,2k+2), specially, A(2n)=0 and we can write A(x)=2[x/2]−[x]. So we have

                                      ∑k=12n(−1)kf(k)=−∫12nA(x)f′(x)dx+A(2n)f(2n)

                                      and the conclusion follows.

                                      7.8

                                      Let φ1(x)=x−[x]−12 if x is not an integer, and let φ1(x)=0 if x is an integer. Also, let φ2(x)=∫0xφ1(t)dt. If f″ is continuous on [1,n] prove that Euler's summation formula implies that

                                      ∑k=1nf(k)=∫1nf(x)dx−∫1nφ2(x)f″(x)dx+f(1)+f(n)2.

                                      Proof

                                      Using Euler’s summation formula we have

                                      ∑k=1nf(k)=∫1nf(x)dx+∫1nf′(x)(x−[x]−12)dx+f(1)+f(n)2

                                      so we only have to prove that

                                      ∫1nf′(x)(x−[x]−12)dx=−∫1nφ2(x)f″(x)dx

                                      Notice that when x shifts from k to k+1, φ1(x) shifts from −1/2 to 1/2, so ∫kk+1φ1(t)dt=0, which means φ2(n)=0 whenever n is a positive integer. Also, f′∈R since f′ is continuous. Use Theorem 7.26 and integration by parts we get

                                      −∫1nφ2(x)f″(x)dx=−∫1nφ2(x)df′(x)=f′(1)φ2(1)−f′(n)φ2(n)+∫1nf′(x)dφ2(x)=∫1nf′(x)dφ2(x)=∫1nf′(x)φ1(x)dx

                                      thus we only have to prove

                                      ∫1nf′(x)(x−[x]−12−φ1(x))dx=0

                                      Let g(x)=x−[x]−12−φ1(x), then g(x)=0 if x is not an integer, and g(x)=−12 if x is an integer. Since f′ is continuous on [1,n], it is bounded and we choose M>1 such that |f′(x)|≤M for x∈[1,n]. For any 0<ε<1, let δ=ε/(Mn) and we have

                                      ∫1nf′(x)g(x)dx=∫11+δf′(x)g(x)dx+∑j=2n−1∫j−δj+δf′(x)g(x)dx+∫n−δnf′(x)g(x)dx

                                      which shall give

                                      |∫1nf′(x)g(x)dx|≤Mδ2+(n−2)Mδ+Mδ2<nMδ<ε

                                      7.9

                                      Take f(x)=log⁡x in Exercise 7.8 and prove that

                                      log⁡n!=(n+12)log⁡n−n+1+∫1nφ2(t)t2dt

                                      Proof

                                      If f(x)=log⁡x then f′(x)=1/x and f″(x)=−1/x2 when x>0. Thus

                                      ∑k=1nf(k)=log⁡n!=∫1nlog⁡xdx+12(log⁡n−log⁡1)+∫1nφ2(t)t2dt

                                      to finish the proof, we see that log⁡1=0 and

                                      ∫1nlog⁡xdx=nlog⁡n−log⁡1−∫1nxdlog⁡x=nlog⁡n−n+1

                                      7.10

                                      If x≥1, let π(x) denote the number of primes ≤x, that is π(x)=∑p≤x1, where the sum is extended over all primes p≤x. The prime number theorem states that

                                      limx→∞π(x)log⁡xx=1

                                      This is usually proved by studying a related function ϑ given by ϑ(x)=∑p≤xlog⁡p, where the sum is extended over all primes p≤x. Both functions π and ϑ are step functions with jumps at the primes. This exercise show how the Riemann-Stieltjes integral can be used to relate these two functions.

                                      a) If x≥2, prove that π(x) and ϑ(x) can be expressed as the following Riemann-Stieltjes integrals:

                                      ϑ(x)=∫3/2xlog⁡tdπ(t),π(x)=∫3/2x1log⁡tdϑ(t).

                                      b) If x≥2, use integration by parts to show that

                                      ϑ(x)=π(x)log⁡x−∫2xπ(t)tdt,π(x)=ϑ(x)log⁡x+∫2xϑ(t)tlog2⁡tdt.

                                      These equations can be used to prove that the prime number theorem is equivalent to the relation limx→∞ϑ(x)/x=1.

                                      Solution

                                      (a) It is easy to see π(x) is discontinuous but right continuous at each prime ≤x, and the jump at each discontinuous is 1. Hence

                                      ∫3/2xlog⁡tdπ(t)=∑p≥3/2p≤xlog⁡p(π(p+)−π(p−))=∑p≤xlog⁡p=ϑ(x)

                                      Similarly, ϑ(x) is discontinuous but right continuous at each prime ≤x, and the jump at p is log⁡p, hence

                                      ∫3/2x1log⁡tdϑ(t)=∑p≥3/2p≤x1log⁡p(ϑ(p+)−ϑ(p−))=∑p≤xlog⁡plog⁡p=π(x)

                                      (b) Notice that π(t)=0 if t<2, use (a) we have

                                      ϑ(x)=π(x)log⁡x−π(3/2)log⁡(3/2)−∫3/2xπ(t)d(log⁡t)=π(x)log⁡x−∫3/22π(t)d(log⁡t)−∫2xπ(t)tdt

                                      since

                                      ∫3/22π(t)d(log⁡t)=π(2)[log⁡2−log⁡(2−)]=0

                                      the first equality holds. Also, notice that ϑ(t)=0 if t<2, and from (a) we have

                                      π(x)=∫3/2x1log⁡tdϑ(t)=ϑ(x)log⁡x−ϑ(3/2)log⁡(3/2)−∫3/2xϑ(t)d(1log⁡t)=ϑ(x)log⁡x−∫3/22ϑ(t)d(1log⁡t)+∫2xϑ(t)tlog2⁡tdt

                                      since

                                      ∫3/22ϑ(t)d(1log⁡t)=ϑ(2)(1log⁡2−1log⁡(2−))=0

                                      the second equality holds.

                                      7.11

                                      If α↗ on [a,b], prove that we have

                                      a) ∫¯abfdα=∫¯acfdα+∫¯cbfdα,(a<c<b).

                                      b) ∫¯ab(f+g)dα≤∫¯abfdα+∫¯abgdα.

                                      c) ∫―ab(f+g)dα≥∫―abfdα+∫―abgdα.

                                      Proof

                                      (a) Let ∀ε>0, there exist a partition P∈P[a,b] such that U(P,f,α)<∫¯abfdα+ε. If c is not in P, we add c to get a refined partition P′, split P′ to P′=P1∪P2 with P1∈P[a,c] and P2∈P[c,b]. So

                                      ∫¯acfdα+∫¯cbfdα≤U(P1,f,α)+U(P2,f,α)=U(P′,f,α)≤U(P,f,α)

                                      which means

                                      (1)∫¯acfdα+∫¯cbfdα<∫¯abfdα+ε

                                      On the other hand, we can choose P1′∈P[a,c] and P2′∈P[c,b] such that

                                      U(P1′,f,α)<∫¯acfdα+ε2,U(P2′,f,α)<∫¯cbfdα+ε2

                                      Let P0=P1′∪P2′, we have

                                      ∫¯abfdα≤U(P0,f,α)=U(P1′,f,α)+U(P2′,f,α)<∫¯acfdα+∫¯cbfdα+ε

                                      combined with (1) we get

                                      ∫¯abfdα−ε<∫¯acfdα+∫¯cbfdα<∫¯abfdα+ε

                                      since ε is arbitrary, the proof is complete.

                                      (b) Let P∈P[a,b], on every segment I of P we have

                                      maxx∈I(f+g)≤maxx∈If+maxx∈Ig⟹U(P,f+g,α)≤U(P,f,α)+U(P,g,α)

                                      which gives

                                      ∫¯ab(f+g)dα≤U(P,f,α)+U(P,g,α)

                                      For any ε>0, choose P1,P2∈P[a,b] such that

                                      U(P1,f,α)<∫¯abfdα+ε2,U(P2,g,α)<∫¯abgdα+ε2

                                      thus

                                      ∫¯ab(f+g)dα≤U(P1∪P2,f+g,α)≤U(P1∪P2,f,α)+U(P1∪P2,g,α)≤U(P1,f,α)+U(P2,g,α)<∫¯abfdα+∫¯abgdα+ε

                                      since ε is arbitrary, the proof is complete.

                                      (c) The proof is similar to (b), ommitted.

                                      7.12

                                      Give an example of a bounded function f and an increasing function α defined on [a,b] such that |f|∈R(α) but for which ∫abfdα does not exist.

                                      Solution

                                      Let f be defined on [a,b] by

                                      f(x)={1,x∈[a,b]∩Q−1,x∈[a,b]−Q

                                      and α(x)=x on [a,b]. Then |f|=1 on [a,b], so |f|∈R, but I¯(f,α)=b−a and I―(f,α)=a−b, thus as long as a<b we will have I¯(f,α)≠I―(f,α), thus ∫abfdα does not exist.

                                      7.13

                                      Let α be a continuous function of bounded variation on [a,b]. Assume g∈R(α) on [a,b] and define β(x)=∫axg(t)dα(t) if x∈[a,b]. Show that:

                                      a) If f↗ on [a,b], there exists a point x0∈[a,b] such that

                                      ∫abfdβ=f(a)∫ax0gdα+f(b)∫x0bgdα.

                                      b) If, in addition, f is continuous on [a,b], we also have

                                      ∫abf(x)g(x)dα(x)=f(a)∫ax0gdα+f(b)∫x0bgdα.

                                      Solution

                                      (a) For ε>0, since g is bounded on [a,b], we have |g|≤M for some M>0, since α is continuous, there exists δ>0 such that for x1,x2∈[a,b], if |x1−x2|<δ, then |α(x1)−α(x2)|<ε/M, this means

                                      |x1−x2|<δ⟹|β(x1)−β(x2)|=|∫x1x2gdα|≤M|∫x1x2dα|<ε

                                      hence β is continuous. Use the second Mean-Value Theorem for Riemann-Stieltjes integrals, there exists a point x0∈[a,b] such that

                                      ∫abf(x)dβ(x)=f(a)∫ax0dβ(x)+f(b)∫x0bdβ(x)

                                      Theorem 7.26 gives ∫ax0dβ(x)=∫ax0g(x)dα(x) and ∫x0bdβ(x)=∫x0bg(x)dα(x).

                                      (b) Theorem 7.27 shows f∈R(α), thus fg∈R(α), Theorem 7.26 gives ∫abf(x)g(x)dα(x)=∫abf(x)dβ(x) and then use (a).

                                      7.14

                                      Assume f∈R(α) on [a,b], where α is of bounded variation on [a,b]. Let V(x) denote the total variation of α on [a,x] for each x∈[a,b], and let V(a)=0. Show that

                                      |∫abfdα|≤∫ab|f|dV≤MV(b),

                                      where M is an upper bound for |f| on [a,b]. In particular, when α(x)=x, the inequality becomes

                                      |∫abf(x)dx|≤M(b−a).

                                      Solution

                                      That f∈R(α) means f∈R(V) and |f|∈R(V), and we have

                                      |∫abfdα|≤∫ab|f|dα,∫ab|f|dV≤M∫abdV=MV(b).

                                      To finish the proof, notice that for any two points x,y∈[a,b] with x<y, we have

                                      α(x)−α(y)≤|α(x)−α(y)|≤V(y)−V(x)

                                      thus

                                      S(P,|f|,α)=∑k|f(tk)|Δαk≤∑k|f(tk)|ΔVk=S(P,|f|,V)

                                      which means ∫ab|f|dα≤∫ab|f|dV. When α(x)=x, we have V(x)=x−a and MV(b)=M(b−a).

                                      7.15

                                      Let {αn} be a sequence of functions of bounded variation on [a,b]. Suppose there exists a function α defined on [a,b] such that the total variation of α−αn on [a,b] tends to 0 as n→∞. Assume also that α(a)=αn(a)=0 for each n=1,2,…. If f is continuous on [a,b], prove that

                                      limn→∞∫abf(x)dαn(x)=∫abf(x)dα(x).

                                      Solution

                                      Since V(α−αn)→0 as n→∞, there exist an integer N such that V(α−αn)<1 if n≥N, since the function αN is of bounded variation on [a,b], we can choose M>0 such that ∑|ΔαN|≤M, given any points x,y∈[a,b] with x<y we have

                                      |α(y)−α(x)|=|Δα|≤|Δ(α−αN)|+|ΔαN|

                                      thus

                                      ∑|Δα|≤∑|Δ(α−αN)|+∑|ΔαN|≤V(α−αN)+M<1+M

                                      this means α is of bounded variation on [a,b], thus f∈R(α).

                                      If f is continuous on [a,b], then there exists M′>0 such that |f|≤M′ on [a,b]. For ∀ε>0, there exists an integer N′ such that V(α−αn)<ε/M′ if n>N′. Since f∈R(α−αn) by Theorem 7.27 and Theorem 7.3, we have

                                      |∫abfd(α−αn)|≤M|[α(b)−αn(b)−α(a)+αn(a)]|≤M′V(α−αn)<ε

                                      thus we have

                                      n>N′⟹|∫abfdα−∫abfdαn|=|∫abfd(α−αn)|<ε

                                      and the conclusion follows.

                                      7.16

                                      If f,f2,g,g2∈R(α) on [a,b], prove that

                                      12∫ab[∫ab|f(x)g(x)f(y)g(y)|2dα(y)]dα(x)=(∫abf2(x)dα(x))(∫abg2(x)dα(x))−(∫abf(x)g(x)dα(x))2.

                                      When α↗ on [a,b], deduce the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality

                                      (∫abf(x)g(x)dα(x))2≤(∫abf2(x)dα(x))(∫abg2(x)dα(x))

                                      Proof

                                      We have

                                      12∫ab[∫ab|f(x)g(x)f(y)g(y)|2dα(y)]dα(x)=12∫ab[∫ab(f(x)g(y)−f(y)g(x))2dα(y)]dα(x)=12∫ab[∫ab(f2(x)g2(y)+f2(y)g2(x)−2f(x)g(x)f(y)g(y))dα(y)]dα(x)=12∫ab[f2(x)∫abg2(y)dα(y)+g2(x)∫abf2(y)dα(y)]dα(x)−∫ab[f(x)g(x)∫abf(y)g(y)dα(y)]dα(x)=12(∫abg2(y)dα(y))(∫abf2(x)dα(x))+(∫abf2(y)dα(y))(∫abg2(x)dα(x))−(∫abf(y)g(y)dα(y))(∫abf(x)g(x)dα(x))=12(∫abg2(x)dα(x))(∫abf2(x)dα(x))+(∫abf2(x)dα(x))(∫abg2(x)dα(x))−(∫abf(x)g(x)dα(x))(∫abf(x)g(x)dα(x))=(∫abf2(x)dα(x))(∫abg2(x)dα(x))−(∫abf(x)g(x)dα(x))2

                                      and when α↗ on [a,b], use Theorem 7.20 we have

                                      ∫ab|f(x)g(x)f(y)g(y)|2dα(y)≥∫ab0dα(y)=0

                                      and

                                      ∫ab[∫ab|f(x)g(x)f(y)g(y)|2dα(y)]dα(x)≥∫ab0dα(x)=0

                                      which shows

                                      (∫abf2(x)dα(x))(∫abg2(x)dα(x))−(∫abf(x)g(x)dα(x))2≥0

                                      and the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality follows.

                                      7.17

                                      Assume that f∈R(α),g∈R(α) and f⋅g∈R(α) on [a,b]. Show that

                                      12∫ab[∫ab(f(y)−f(x))(g(y)−g(x))dα(y)]dα(x)=(α(b)−α(a))∫abf(x)g(x)dα(x)−(∫abf(x)dα(x))(∫abg(x)dα(x))

                                      If α↗ on [a,b], deduce the inequality

                                      (∫abf(x)dα(x))(∫abg(x)dα(x))≤(α(b)−α(a))∫abf(x)g(x)dα(x)

                                      when both f and g are increasing (or both are decreasing) on [a,b]. Show that the reverse inequality holds if f increases and g decreases on [a,b].

                                      Proof

                                      For convenience we denote

                                      A=∫abf(x)dα(x),B=∫abg(x)dα(x),C=∫abf(x)g(x)dα(x)

                                      then we have

                                      ∫ab(f(y)−f(x))(g(y)−g(x))dα(y)=∫ab(f(y)g(y)+f(x)g(x)−f(x)g(y)−f(y)g(x))dα(y)=∫abf(y)g(y)dα(y)+f(x)g(x)∫abdα(y)−f(x)∫abg(y)dα(y)−g(x)∫abf(y)dα(y)=C+f(x)g(x)[α(b)−α(a)]−Bf(x)−Ag(x)

                                      hence

                                      ∫ab[∫ab(f(y)−f(x))(g(y)−g(x))dα(y)]dα(x)=∫ab(C+f(x)g(x)[α(b)−α(a)]−Bf(x)−Ag(x))dα(x)=[α(b)−α(a)][C+∫abf(x)g(x)dα(x)]−B∫abf(x)dα(x)−A∫abg(x)dα(x)=2[α(b)−α(a)]C−BA−AB=2[α(b)−α(a)]C−2AB

                                      thus we have

                                      12∫ab[∫ab(f(y)−f(x))(g(y)−g(x))dα(y)]dα(x)=[α(b)−α(a)]C−AB

                                      when α↗ on [a,b], we see that if both f and g are increasing (or both are decreasing) on [a,b], then (f(y)−f(x))(g(y)−g(x))≥0 for any x,y∈[a,b], thus use Theorem 7.20 we see the original integral ≥0. If f increases and g decreases on [a,b], then for any x,y∈[a,b] we have (f(y)−f(x))(g(y)−g(x))≤0, so the original integral ≤0 and the reverse inequality holds.
